query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
7 Noi demmo il dosso al misero vallone 8 su per la ripa che ’l cinge dintorno, 9 attraversando sanza alcun sermone.
query.result:
**English:**
7 We turned our backs on the wretched valley 8 and climbed the bank that encircles it all around, 9 crossing over without speaking a word.
**Old English:**
7 We forleton ðone wædla wænne 8 uppon ðone hlæw ðe hine ymbclyppeð, 9 ðurh ða dene butan ænigum spræce.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
10 Quiv’ era men che notte e men che giorno, 11 sì che ’l viso m’andava innanzi poco; 12 ma io senti’ sonare un alto corno,
13 tanto ch’avrebbe ogne tuon fatto fioco, 14 che, contra sé la sua via seguitando, 15 dirizzò li occhi miei tutti ad un loco.
query.result:
**English:**
10 Here it was less than night and less than day, 11 so that my vision went forward but a little; 12 but I heard a loud horn sound,
13 so loud that it would have made any thunder seem faint, 14 which, following its way against itself, 15 directed my eyes all to one place.
**Old English:**
10 Þær wæs lyt ðonne niht and lyt ðonne dæg, 11 swa ðæt ðæt gesihð me forð gewat lyt; 12 ac ic gehyrde ðær hlude horn blawan,
13 swa ðæt ælc ðunor ðuhte me lyt ðærwið, 14 ðæt, ongean hine his weg secende, 15 gerihte mine eagan ealle to anum stede.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
16 Dopo la dolorosa rotta, quando 17 Carlo Magno perdé la santa gesta, 18 non sonò sì terribilmente Orlando.
query.result:
**English:**
16 After the sorrowful rout, when 17 Charlemagne lost the holy army, 18 Orlando did not sound his horn so terribly.
**Old English:**
16 Æfter ðære heanlicum hryre, ða 17 Carl se cyning forleas his cempan, 18 ne bleow swa ðæs beorna byme.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
19 Poco portäi in là volta la testa, 20 che me parve veder molte alte torri; 21 ond’ io: «Maestro, dì, che terra è questa?».
query.result:
**English:**
19 I had turned my head a little way, 20 when it seemed to me that I saw many high towers; 21 and I said: "Master, tell me, what land is this?".
**Old English:**
19 Ic wæs lyt gehworfen on ðære stede, 20 ða ðuhte me ðæt ic gesawe ðær torras swiðe heah; 21 ða cwæð ic: "Lareow, sege me, hwæt is ðeos stow?".

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
22 Ed elli a me: «Però che tu trascorri 23 per le tenebre troppo da la lungi, 24 avvien che poi nel maginare abborri.
query.result:
**English:**
22 And he to me: "Because you stray 23 too far through the darkness, 24 it happens that then in your imagination you are terrified.
**Old English:**
22 And he to me: "Forðæm ðe ðu ðurh ða ðystro farast 23 to ðam miclum ðe ðu ðone magon forbugan, 24 ðonne bið ðæt ðin mod ðurh ða myrcðu afyrht.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
25 Tu vedrai ben, se tu là ti congiungi, 26 quanto ’l senso s’inganna di lontano; 27 però alquanto più te stesso pungi».
query.result:
**English:**
25 You will see well, if you join with them there, 26 how much the senses are deceived from afar; 27 therefore spur yourself on a little more.
**Old English:**
25 ðu gesyhst wel gif ðu ðærtogeþegnest, 26 hu ðæt gesihð bið swiðe gedwolen feorran; 27 forðæm ðe selfne ðu scealt lyt swiðor prician.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
28 Poi caramente mi prese per mano 29 e disse: «Pria che noi siam più avanti, 30 acciò che ’l fatto men ti paia strano,
31 sappi che non son torri, ma giganti, 32 e son nel pozzo intorno da la ripa 33 da l’umbilico in giuso tutti quanti».
query.result:
**English:**
28 Then he took me gently by the hand 29 and said: “Before we go any further, 30 so that the matter may seem less strange to you,
31 know that these are not towers, but giants, 32 and they are all around the well, from the edge 33 down to their navels.”
**Old English:**
28 Þa genam he mildelice mine hand 29 and cwæð: “Ærðon ðe we sigefæste, 30 ðæt ðe ðæt geweorc ðince læsse wundor,
31 wite ðu ðæt ðis ne sind noh turras, ac gigantas, 32 and hi beoð on ðam pytte ymbutan ða rip 33 of ðam nafalan and niðorweard ealle.”

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
34 Come quando la nebbia si dissipa, 35 lo sguardo a poco a poco raffigura 36 ciò che cela ’l vapor che l’aere stipa,
37 così forando l’aura grossa e scura, 38 più e più appressando ver’ la sponda, 39 fuggiemi errore e cresciemi paura;
40 però che, come su la cerchia tonda 41 Montereggion di torri si corona, 42 così la proda che ’l pozzo circonda
43 torreggiavan di mezza la persona 44 li orribili giganti, cui minaccia 45 Giove del cielo ancora quando tuona.
query.result:
**English:**
34 As when the mist dissipates, 35 the sight little by little distinguishes 36 what the vapor that thickens the air conceals,
37 so, piercing the thick and gloomy air, 38 drawing nearer and nearer to the bank, 39 error fled from me and fear grew;
40 because, just as on the round summit 41 of Montereggione a crown of towers stands, 42 so the edge that encircles the pit
43 towered with half the bodies 44 of the horrible giants, whom Jove 45 still threatens from the sky when he thunders.
**Old English:**
34 Swa swa ðonne mist forðgeð, 35 ðæt gesihð ðurh ðæt lytle and lytle 36 ðæt ðe ðone wæstm beheleð ðe ðone lyft bregð,
37 swa ðurh ða ðiccan lyft and ðone dimman, 38 nealæcande ðære strande swiðor and swiðor, 39 flugon fram me gedwimor and weoxon ege;
40 forðæm ðe, swa swa ofer ðone hring ðone healican 41 Muntregis ofer torras stondeð, 42 swa ða ofre ðe ðone pytt betyndon
43 torrodon mid healfum lichoman 44 ða egeslican entas, ðe Giof 45 ðreatode of heofonum ða ða he ðunrode.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
46 E io scorgeva già d’alcun la faccia, 47 le spalle e ’l petto e del ventre gran parte, 48 e per le coste giù ambo le braccia.
query.result:
**English:**
46 And already I could make out someone’s face, 47 his shoulders and chest and a large part of his belly, 48 and down along his sides both arms.
**Old English:**
46 And ic ða geseah ðara sumes muð, 47 eaxle and breost and ðæs bukes micel, 48 and be ðam sidan ba ða earmas.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
49 Natura certo, quando lasciò l’arte 50 di sì fatti animali, assai fé bene 51 per tòrre tali essecutori a Marte.
query.result:
**English:**
49 Nature certainly, when she abandoned the art 50 of such animals, did very well 51 in order to take such executioners away from Mars.
**Old English:**
49 Gewiss, ða ðe gecynd forlêt ðone cræft 50 swylcra nytena, wel hio ða dyde 51 ðæt heo ða slean mid ðam gefeohte afyrde.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
58 La faccia sua mi parea lunga e grossa 59 come la pina di San Pietro a Roma, 60 e a sua proporzione eran l’altre ossa;
61 sì che la ripa, ch’era perizoma 62 dal mezzo in giù, ne mostrava ben tanto 63 di sovra, che di giugnere a la chioma
64 tre Frison s’averien dato mal vanto; 65 però ch’i’ ne vedea trenta gran palmi 66 dal loco in giù dov’ omo affibbia ’l manto.
query.result:
**English:**
58 His face seemed to me long and large 59 as the pine cone of St. Peter's in Rome, 60 and his other bones were in proportion;
61 so that the bank, which was like a loincloth 62 from the waist down, showed us clearly 63 so much of him above that three Frisians
64 would have boasted in vain to reach his hair; 65 for I could see thirty great spans 66 from the place where a man buckles his cloak down.
**Old English:**
58 His neb me ðuhte lang and brad 59 swa ðæs hwerhwæles ðe on hliðe standeð, 60 and his eagan swa swa twegen discas,
61 ða ðe on niht beoð ofer heofenum gesiene, 62 ðonne hi scinað scip-flotan on sæ; 63 his teð wæron swa twegen wilde-swin,
64 ða ðe wudurofum wrotad on holt; 65 his lichoma wæs swa mære and swa micel 66 swa ðæs huses ðac ðe hæðnum men
67 aræran on heora hæðenscipe, 68 ðær hi heora hæðene godas to wurðiað.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
67 «Raphèl maì amècche zabì almi», 68 cominciò a gridar la fiera bocca, 69 cui non si convenia più dolci salmi.
query.result:
**English:**
67 "Raphèl maì amècche zabì almi", 68 began to cry the fierce mouth, 69 to which sweeter psalms were not fitting.
**Old English:**
67 "Raphèl maì amècche zabì almi", 68 ongan ða gryreleoð galan, 69 ðam ne gebyrede ðæt he softe sprecan sceolde.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
70 E ’l duca mio ver’ lui: «Anima sciocca, 71 tienti col corno, e con quel ti disfoga 72 quand’ ira o altra passïon ti tocca!
73 Cércati al collo, e troverai la soga 74 che ’l tien legato, o anima confusa, 75 e vedi lui che ’l gran petto ti doga».
query.result:
**English:**
70 And my leader said to him: "Foolish soul, 71 hold yourself with the horn, and with that vent 72 whenever anger or other passion touches you!
73 Search your neck, and you will find the rope 74 that holds you bound, O confused soul, 75 and see him who pierces your great chest."
**Old English:**
70 And min heretoga cwæð to him: "Wudu sceocca, 71 healde ðe mid ðinum horne, and mid ðam ðe selfne gebliss, 72 ðonne ðe yrre oððe oðer ðing hrepað!
73 Sec ðe on ðinum sweoran, and ðu ðær findest ða strengas 74 ðe ðe geheftað, ðu gedwolena gast, 75 and geseoh ðone ðe ðinne miclan breost sticað."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
76 Poi disse a me: «Elli stessi s’accusa; 77 questi è Nembrotto per lo cui mal coto 78 pur un linguaggio nel mondo non s’usa.
query.result:
**English:**
76 Then he said to me: "Elli herself accuses him; 77 this is Nimrod, through whose evil plan 78 only one language is not used in the world.
**Old English:**
76 Þa cwæð he to me: "Elli hire selfne wregð; 77 þes is Nembroð, ðurh ðæs yflan geþoht 78 an ðæt anlicnes ne bið on eorðan."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
79 Lasciànlo stare e non parliamo a vòto; 80 ché così è a lui ciascun linguaggio 81 come ’l suo ad altrui, ch’a nullo è noto».
query.result:
**English:**
79 Let us leave him alone and not speak in vain; 80 for to him every language is 81 like his own to others, which is known to none.
**Old English:**
79 Læte we hine licgan and ne ceorfon ymbe; 80 forðæm him is æghwylc spræc 81 swylce his agen ðe nan man ne can.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
82 Facemmo adunque più lungo vïaggio, 83 vòlti a sinistra; e al trar d’un balestro 84 trovammo l’altro assai più fero e maggio.
query.result:
**English:**
82 We made a longer journey, then, 83 turned to the left; and at a crossbow's shot 84 we found the other, much fiercer and larger.
**Old English:**
82 We macodon ða lengran fyrde, 83 wendon on ða wynstran hond; and æt anum ballistan sceote 84 we fundon ðone oðerne mycelne and fyrnlicorne.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
85 A cigner lui qual che fosse ’l maestro, 86 non so io dir, ma el tenea soccinto 87 dinanzi l’altro e dietro il braccio destro
88 d’una catena che ’l tenea avvinto 89 dal collo in giù, sì che ’n su lo scoperto 90 si ravvolgëa infino al giro quinto.
query.result:
**English:**
85 To ask him who his teacher was, 86 I do not know how to say, but he held him bound 87 in front with the other and behind with the right arm
88 by a chain that held him bound 89 from the neck down, so that on the exposed part 90 it wound itself up to the fifth coil.
**Old English:**
85 To acsianne hine hwæt his lareow wære, 86 ne can ic ðæt secgan, ac he hine hæfde gebunden 87 beforan oðrum and beæftan ðone swiðran earm
88 mid anum racenteagan ðe hine ræhte 89 of ðam sweoran niðer, swa ðæt on ðam bare 90 hit bewunden wæs oð ðone fifte hring.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
91 «Questo superbo volle esser esperto 92 di sua potenza contra ’l sommo Giove», 93 disse ’l mio duca, «ond’ elli ha cotal merto.
query.result:
**English:**
91 "This proud one wanted to test 92 his power against the highest Jove," 93 said my guide, "and for that he has such a reward.
**Old English:**
91 Þes ofermoda wolde beon ondspeorf 92 his mihte ongean ðone hehstan God, 93 cwæð min latteow, "and forðæm he hæfð ðone medscipe.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
94 Fïalte ha nome, e fece le gran prove 95 quando i giganti fer paura a’ dèi; 96 le braccia ch’el menò, già mai non move».
query.result:
**English:**
94 He is called Fialte, and he performed great feats 95 when the giants frightened the gods; 96 the arms that he wielded, he never moves again.
**Old English:**
94 He is nemned Fialte, and he worhte ða miclan dad 95 ða ða ða gigantas Gode wæron gram; 96 ða earmas ðe he ongann, he næfre eft ne onhrærð.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
97 E io a lui: «S’esser puote, io vorrei 98 che de lo smisurato Brïareo 99 esperïenza avesser li occhi mei».
query.result:
**English:**
97 And I to him: "If it is possible, I would like 98 to have my eyes experience the immense Briareus."
**Old English:**
97 And ic to him: "Gif hit gewurðan mæg, ic wolde 98 ðæt ðæs unmætan Briareus 99 andwlita mine eagan ongeotan."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
100 Ond’ ei rispuose: «Tu vedrai Anteo 101 presso di qui che parla ed è disciolto, 102 che ne porrà nel fondo d’ogne reo.
query.result:
**English:**
100 And he replied: "You will see Antaeus 101 near here, who speaks and is unloosed, 102 who will place us in the depths of every evil."
**Old English:**
100 And he andswarode: "Þu scealt geseon Anteon 101 neah ðisum ðe spriceð and is unbunden, 102 se ðe willeð settan on ðæs helle grund."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
103 Quel che tu vuo’ veder, più là è molto 104 ed è legato e fatto come questo, 105 salvo che più feroce par nel volto».
query.result:
**English:**
103 That which you wish to see is much farther on, 104 and it is bound and made like this one, 105 except that it seems more fierce in its face."
**Old English:**
103 Þæt ðu woldest geseon, þæt is fela lengra, 104 and is gebunden and geworht swilce þeos, 105 buton ðæt hit is grymlicor on gesihðe."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
106 Non fu tremoto già tanto rubesto, 107 che scotesse una torre così forte, 108 come Fïalte a scuotersi fu presto.
query.result:
**English:**
106 There was never an earthquake so violent 107 that it shook a tower so strongly, 108 as Fialte was quick to shake himself.
**Old English:**
106 Ne wearð æfre eorðstyrunga swa strong, 107 ðe ðone torr swa ðohte, 108 swa ðe ða Fialte feorhgeniðlan ðohte.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
109 Allor temett’ io più che mai la morte, 110 e non v’era mestier più che la dotta, 111 s’io non avessi viste le ritorte.
query.result:
**English:**
109 Then I feared death more than ever, 110 and there was no need for more than fear, 111 if I had not seen the bonds.
**Old English:**
109 Þa ic ðær ðone dead ondræd me selfne mare ðonne æfre ær, 110 and næs ðær nænig neod mare ðonne ðæt an ðæt ic ða bendas ne gesawe. 111 Gif ic ða bendas ne gesawe.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
112 Noi procedemmo più avante allotta, 113 e venimmo ad Anteo, che ben cinque alle, 114 sanza la testa, uscia fuor de la grotta.
query.result:
**English:**
112 We proceeded farther onward, 113 and we came to Antaeus, who, without his head, 114 stood forth from the cave, fully five ells.
**Old English:**
112 We forð gewendon forðor on ðone weg, 113 and comon ða to Anteon ðe ða ða fif elne, 114 buton ðam heafde, of ðære græf ut stod.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
115 «O tu che ne la fortunata valle 116 che fece Scipïon di gloria reda, 117 quand’ Anibàl co’ suoi diede le spalle,
118 recasti già mille leon per preda, 119 e che, se fossi stato a l’alta guerra 120 de’ tuoi fratelli, ancor par che si creda
121 ch’avrebber vinto i figli de la terra: 122 mettine giù, e non ten vegna schifo, 123 dove Cocito la freddura serra.
query.result:
**English:**
115 O you who in the fortunate valley 116 that made Scipio heir to glory, 117 when Hannibal and his men turned their backs,
118 once brought back a thousand lions as prey, 119 and if you had been at the great war 120 of your brothers, it still seems to be believed
121 that the sons of earth would have won: 122 put us down, and do not be disgusted by it, 123 where Cocytus locks up the cold.
**Old English:**
115 Eala ðu ðe on ðære gesæligan dene 116 ðe Scipio to wuldre geworhte, 117 ða ða Annibal mid his folce fleah,
118 ðu ða ðusend leona ær to herehlafe brohtest, 119 and gif ðu on ðære miclan gefeohte wære 120 ðinra gebroðra, ða gyt ys to geleafanne
121 ðæt ða eorðan bearn sige hæfdon: 122 læt us nu nyðer, and ðe ðæs ne beo lað, 123 ðær Cocytus ða cealdan locð.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
124 Non ci fare ire a Tizio né a Tifo: 125 questi può dar di quel che qui si brama; 126 però ti china e non torcer lo grifo.
query.result:
**English:**
124 Do not make us go to Tityus or Typhon: 125 this one can give what is desired here; 126 therefore bow down and do not turn up your nose.
**Old English:**
124 Ne læt ðu us faran to Titius ne to Typhon: 125 ðes mæg gifan ðæt ðe her is gewilnod; 126 forðæm gebig ðe and ne wend ðu ðinne nosu.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
127 Ancor ti può nel mondo render fama, 128 ch’el vive, e lunga vita ancor aspetta 129 se ’nnanzi tempo grazia a sé nol chiama».
query.result:
**English:**
127 Still can fame restore you to the world, 128 for he lives and still expects a long life, 129 unless grace calls him to itself before his time.
**Old English:**
127 Þeáh ðe mæg ðin lof lifigende beon, 128 and lange lif habban, gif ðe ðin wyrd ne gesceóð, 129 buton ðe ær his tid God to him gecyrre.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
130 Così disse ’l maestro; e quelli in fretta 131 le man distese, e prese ’l duca mio, 132 ond’ Ercule sentì già grande stretta.
query.result:
**English:**
130 Thus spoke the master; and those in haste 131 stretched out their hands, and seized my leader, 132 so that Hercules once felt a great grip.
**Old English:**
130 Þus cwæð se lareow; and ða on fyrhte 131 ða handa bræddon, and fengon minum heretogan, 132 ðær ðe Ercol ðolode ær micle geswinc.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
133 Virgilio, quando prender si sentio, 134 disse a me: «Fatti qua, sì ch’io ti prenda»; 135 poi fece sì ch’un fascio era elli e io.
query.result:
**English:**
133 Virgil, when he felt himself seized, 134 said to me: "Come here, so that I may take you"; 135 then he made it so that he and I were one bundle.
**Old English:**
133 Firgilius, ða he hine gebundenne ongeat, 134 cwæð to me: "Gecyr ðu her, ðæt ic ðe genime"; 135 ða dyde he swa ðæt he and ic wæron an byrðen.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
136 Qual pare a riguardar la Carisenda 137 sotto ’l chinato, quando un nuvol vada 138 sovr’ essa sì, ched ella incontro penda:
139 tal parve Antëo a me che stava a bada 140 di vederlo chinare, e fu tal ora 141 ch’i’ avrei voluto ir per altra strada.
query.result:
**English:**
136 As seems the Carisenda to look 137 beneath the leaning side, when a cloud passes 138 over it so that it hangs opposite:
139 such Antaeus seemed to me, who was watching 140 to see him stoop, and there was a time 141 when I would have wished to go by another road.
**Old English:**
136 Swa swa ðære Carisendan ðynceð to locian 137 under ðam gehnigendan, ðonne wolcen gæð 138 ofer ða swiðe, ðæt heo on ða healfe hange:
139 swylc ðuhte Antæus me ða ðe ic ðær abad 140 ðæt ic hine gesawe hnigende, and wæs ða tid 141 ðe ic wolde habban farenne oðre stræte.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
142 Ma lievemente al fondo che divora 143 Lucifero con Giuda, ci sposò; 144 né, sì chinato, lì fece dimora,
145 e come albero in nave si levò.
query.result:
**English:**
142 But gently down to the bottom that devours 143 Lucifer with Judas, he conveyed us; 144 nor, thus stooping, did he there make stay,
145 but, like a mast in a ship, he raised himself.
**Old English:**
142 Ac liðelice on ðone grund ðe forswealg 143 Lucifer mid Iudan, he us lædde; 144 ne, swa abugen, ðær ða wunode,
145 ac swa mæst on scipe he hine geræhte.
